data.title: Azerion Group (ENXTAM:AZRN) FY 2025 Losses Persist And Test Bullish Revaluation Narrative
data.description:

Latest FY 2025 results at a glance

Azerion Group (ENXTAM:AZRN) has wrapped up FY 2025 with fourth quarter revenue of ‚Ç¨169.5 million and a net income loss from continuing operations, excluding extra items, of ‚Ç¨19.9 million, with earnings from discontinued operations coming in at a loss of ‚Ç¨1.6 million. Over the past few quarters the company has seen revenue move from ‚Ç¨115.6 million in Q1 2025 to ‚Ç¨135.7 million in Q2 and ‚Ç¨119.8 million in Q3, while losses excluding extra items shifted from ‚Ç¨14.8 million to ‚Ç¨6.7 million and ‚Ç¨14 million respectively. This gives investors a clearer read on how top line scale is interacting with persistent bottom line pressure. With the trailing twelve month numbers still pointing to an overall loss of ‚Ç¨55.1 million on ‚Ç¨540.6 million of revenue, the focus now turns to whether margins can tighten enough for that revenue base to translate into more sustainable profitability.

‚Ç¨55.1 million loss alongside ‚Ç¨540.6 million in revenue

  • For a more bullish interpretation, the multi year data in the analysis mentions losses narrowing by about 4% a year on average over five years. This sits alongside the current ‚Ç¨55.1 million loss on a sizeable ‚Ç¨540.6 million revenue base, so optimists focus on the idea that a large existing operation has been slowly reducing its drag on the income statement.
    • Supporters point to the pattern of annual loss reduction as a sign the model has been tightening over time, even though the latest trailing twelve month figures still show a loss.
    • At the same time, the fact that revenue is already over half a billion euros while the company remains unprofitable challenges any bullish view that scale alone is enough to flip earnings quickly.

That view, however, has to be balanced against the fact that Azerion is currently loss making and that the very low multiple suggests investors are already heavily discounting those revenues.
    • The contrast between a sub 1x P/S and ongoing net income losses of ‚Ç¨55.1 million means the valuation gap could be reflecting concern about how efficiently that revenue converts into profit.

  • Supporters of a more optimistic stance see that gap as a key part of the bullish case. At the same time, the fact that Azerion remains unprofitable with a trailing loss of ‚Ç¨55.1 million on ‚Ç¨540.6 million of revenue is a clear reminder that any DCF output is being applied to a company that still needs to close the distance between its revenue and its costs.
    • The bullish angle is that if the multi year pattern of around 4% annual loss reduction continues, the current price near ‚Ç¨0.97 could already reflect a lot of pessimism compared with the ‚Ç¨5.52 DCF fair value figure.
    • The counterpoint is that as long as the income statement shows continuing losses, the market can remain cautious even when model based values point much higher, so the valuation gap and the loss profile have to be weighed together.

data.title: Sweetgreen Q4 Loss Worsening To US$49.7 Million Tests Bullish Profitability Narrative
data.description:
Sweetgreen (SG) just closed out FY 2025 with Q4 revenue of US$155.2 million and a basic EPS loss of US$0.42, while trailing 12 month revenue came in at US$679.5 million with a TTM basic EPS loss of US$1.14. Over the year, the company has seen quarterly revenue shift from US$166.3 million in Q1 and US$185.6 million in Q2 to US$172.4 million in Q3 and US$155.2 million in Q4, with basic EPS losses ranging from US$0.21 to US$0.42 per quarter. With TTM net losses still substantial and same restaurant sales moving from growth in 2024 to declines through 2025, the focus for investors now is firmly on whether Sweetgreen can tighten unit economics and protect margins as it adds new restaurants.

See our full analysis for Sweetgreen.

With the latest numbers on the table, the next step is to see how this earnings print compares with the main narratives around Sweetgreen's growth potential, path to profitability, and the risks investors are watching most closely.

See what the community is saying about Sweetgreen

Advertisement

Same store sales slide from +6% to mid single digit declines

  • Same restaurant sales went from 6% growth in Q4 2024 to declines of 3.1%, 7.6% and 9.5% across the first three quarters of 2025, even as the store count rose from 246 to 266 locations.
  • Bulls argue that Infinite Kitchens and new formats can lift unit economics. The shift from 6% growth to a 9.5% decline tests that view, because:
    • Rising total restaurants through 2025 shows expansion continuing while like for like sales turn negative, which can dilute average unit volumes if traffic does not keep up.
    • The bullish focus on better margins per store sits against FY 2025 trailing 12 month net losses of US$134.1 million, so the financial impact of newer formats is not yet visible at the consolidated level.

Bulls point to automation and new formats as future growth drivers, but these results show how much has to go right for that thesis to play out. üêÇ Sweetgreen Bull Case

Losses widen to US$49.7 million in Q4

  • Net loss in Q4 2025 was US$49.7 million versus US$29.0 million in Q4 2024, and on a trailing 12 month basis losses were US$134.1 million with basic EPS at a loss of US$1.14.
  • Bears focus on rising costs and execution issues, and the numbers give that argument some backing, because:
    • Across 2025, quarterly net losses moved from US$25.0 million in Q1 to US$23.2 million in Q2, US$36.1 million in Q3 and US$49.7 million in Q4, so the company is not yet showing a clear path toward break even at the income statement level.
    • Forecasts indicating the company remains unprofitable over the next three years, combined with a cash runway of under one year, line up with the cautious view that ongoing investment and higher costs could keep pressure on margins.

If you are weighing whether these losses are temporary growing pains or something more structural, it helps to see how skeptics frame the downside. üêª Sweetgreen Bear Case

P/S around 1x with slower forecast growth

  • With trailing 12 month revenue of US$679.5 million and a P/S of 1.0x that sits below peers at 1.3x and the US hospitality average at 1.7x, the market is pricing Sweetgreen at a discount while revenue is forecast to grow at 7.2% a year versus 10.3% for the broader US market.
  • Consensus narrative highlights reduced losses over five years and a lower P/S multiple, but the current print adds some tension to that view, because:
    • The five year loss reduction trend of roughly 9.7% a year contrasts with the latest trailing 12 month net loss of US$134.1 million, which has not yet reflected any move toward the industry profit margin of 8.2% that analysts often reference.
    • The current share price of US$5.55 sits below the single allowed analyst price target of US$7.42, so anyone relying on that target has to reconcile the discount P/S and slower forecast growth with the ongoing lack of profitability.

data.title: Aurinia Pharmaceuticals (AUPH) Earnings Spike Above Revenue Challenges Profit Quality Narratives
data.description:
Aurinia Pharmaceuticals (AUPH) closed FY 2025 with Q4 revenue of US$77.1 million and basic EPS of US$1.60, alongside trailing twelve month EPS of US$2.14 on revenue of US$283.1 million. This frames a very strong headline earnings story. Over the past few quarters, the company has seen revenue move from US$59.9 million in Q4 2024 to US$77.1 million in Q4 2025, while quarterly EPS shifted from roughly breakeven at US$0.01 to US$1.60, with trailing twelve month net income reaching US$287.2 million. For investors, the key question now is how durable these higher profit margins are and what they imply for the quality of earnings going forward.

See our full analysis for Aurinia Pharmaceuticals.

With the headline numbers set, the next step is to line these results up against the main narratives around Aurinia, highlighting where the recent margin profile backs the story and where it raises fresh questions.

See what the community is saying about Aurinia Pharmaceuticals

Advertisement

TTM net income now slightly ahead of revenue

  • On a trailing twelve month basis, Aurinia reported net income of US$287.2 million on revenue of US$283.1 million, which means reported profit is slightly larger than sales over the same period.
  • What stands out for the bullish narrative is how this very high reported profitability sits alongside claims of stronger LUPKYNIS adoption and cost discipline:
    • Bulls point to three year efficacy data and updated treatment guidelines as drivers of revenue momentum. The trailing revenue line at US$283.1 million gives that story some support, even though part of the earnings jump is flagged as non cash.
    • At the same time, the sharp step up from quarterly net income of US$1.4 million in Q4 2024 to US$210.8 million in Q4 2025 is so extreme that it invites the question of how much is repeatable operating profit versus one off or accounting driven items that bullish investors need to separate out.

Some investors see this earnings profile as the start of a stronger long term story, while others are more cautious about how much of it is sustainable.

üêÇ Aurinia Pharmaceuticals Bull Case

Low 6.4x P/E versus high growth backdrop

  • The shares trade on a P/E of 6.4x against a current price of US$13.97, while revenue is described as forecast to grow about 11.7% per year and TTM EPS sits at US$2.14.
  • Bears highlight that even this low multiple may be justified if the quality of those earnings is weaker than it looks and if profits ease back from here:
    • The risk summary flags that a large portion of earnings is non cash, so the gap between US$287.2 million of TTM net income and the revenue line can challenge the idea that the stock simply looks cheap on headline EPS.
    • Analyst models pointing to roughly 5.1% annual earnings declines over the next three years run against the very strong trailing profit picture, which supports the bearish view that the current 6.4x P/E might already be factoring in some of this pressure.

For you as an investor, the tension between a low P/E and earnings forecasts is where a lot of the debate is happening.

üêª Aurinia Pharmaceuticals Bear Case

DCF fair value far above current price

  • The DCF fair value provided is US$41.93 per share versus the current share price of US$13.97, while the only allowed analyst price target reference here is US$16.67, so both reference points sit above where the stock trades today.
  • Consensus narrative views this gap through the lens of both opportunities and risks, and the recent financials give you data for each side:
    • On the opportunity side, analysts expect revenue to grow 14.1% per year with profit margins moving from 23.3% to 36.6%, and TTM margins are already described as 2.4 percentage points higher than a year ago. This lines up with a story of improving economics.
    • On the risk side, the same consensus flags that earnings are expected to be around US$141.3 million by 2028, well below the current TTM net income of US$287.2 million. This signals that the recent profitability spike is not being treated as a permanent baseline in those models.

That mix of a higher DCF fair value and more cautious earnings forecasts is why it helps to separate one off strength from what you think Aurinia can produce year in, year out.

data.description:

  • Analysts' consensus view highlights strong brand and pricing power as key supports for earnings, and the current figures partly back that up while also setting some limits:

  • Over the last 12 months, Neinor Homes earned ‚Ç¨123.4 million on ‚Ç¨697.5 million of revenue, which works out to a 17.7% net margin compared with 12.7% a year earlier, even though the latest half year net income of ‚Ç¨3.2 million on ‚Ç¨146.2 million of revenue is much lower than the ‚Ç¨52.3 million on ‚Ç¨316.3 million booked in the second half of 2024.
  • Consensus narrative points to margin expansion supported by pricing power, and the current 17.7% trailing net margin lines up with that, but
    • the first half of 2025 shows net income of ‚Ç¨3.2 million versus ‚Ç¨9.7 million in the first half of 2024, which means the recent margin strength is concentrated in other periods rather than this latest half alone,
    • and the risk summary flags a high level of non cash earnings, so part of the 17.7% margin may not reflect cash profitability in the way bulls focused on ‚Äústrong forward visibility in revenues and potential upside in top line growth‚Äù might hope.

Bulls point to strong demand and pricing power, but this mix of higher trailing margin and weaker latest half profit makes it important to see how much of that margin comes from repeatable cash earnings. üêÇ Neinor Homes Bull Case

P/E of 15.2x versus peers at 35x

  • The stock trades on a trailing P/E of 15.2x compared with roughly 35x for peers, 16x for the wider European Consumer Durables industry and 16.9x for the Spanish market, while the current share price of ‚Ç¨19.06 sits above a DCF fair value of about ‚Ç¨16.09.
  • Skeptics highlight that reported earnings grew 99% over the last year but have fallen about 3.4% per year over five years and are forecast to decline about 12.6% per year, and
    • the discount to peer P/E multiples fits with that cautious view because a lower multiple is paired with forecasts for earnings and revenue to each decline over the next three years,
    • while the gap between the ‚Ç¨19.06 share price and the ‚Ç¨16.09 DCF fair value echoes the concern that some of the recent earnings strength may already be reflected in the price even as analysts expect earnings pressure ahead.

Bears focus on the lower P/E and the premium to DCF fair value as signs that forecasts for softer earnings are already weighing on how the stock is valued. üêª Neinor Homes Bear Case

99% earnings jump meets dilution risk

  • Over the last 12 months, reported earnings almost doubled, rising 99% on a trailing basis, yet the analysis flags significant shareholder dilution in the past year alongside expectations for earnings to decline about 12.6% per year and revenue about 1% per year over the next three years.
  • What stands out for the consensus narrative that leans on ‚Äúscalable, capital light growth‚Äù and ‚Äústrong institutional investment access‚Äù is that
    • the 99% trailing earnings improvement sits next to a five year earnings trend of about 3.4% annual decline, showing that the recent jump is not the long term pattern that the growth story implies,
    • and the flagged shareholder dilution plus an unstable dividend track record contrasts with the idea of consistently efficient capital recycling and cash returns that some long term holders might be hoping for.
